Unlike other games (i.e. Megaman series, Metroid series, or the more recent Batman series) in which upgrades were tied to the story, expanded your combat interaction and strategy when dealing with old & new enemies, as well as reveal previously innaccessable areas; Prince of persia sits content to make upgrades only usable in a small number of locations, and powers that have no real relation to the story or game (minus one power that lets you run along walls on a preset path, almost like a rail segment). Enemy types are rather simplistic and most of them are the same type of enemy with merely a different skin applied. Bosses offer little to know variation in how you defeat them, boiling down to: counter, strike, use "x", "b", or "y" attacks.The goal of the game boils down to collecting "light seeds" to unlock the next upgrade, fight one of the same 4 bosses and move on to the next point. Movement (free running) in this game feels almost prehistoric with many actions feeling almost like a quick time event where you are just pressing a button instead of actually maneuvering around the environment. compared to many free roam game out there (assassins creed, mirrors edge) the free running and acrobatics in this game feel rather clunky and unpolished. add to this the fact that by the second area you have seen everything this game has to offer (minus the severly limited upgrades) you feel more like you're running through the motions than actually playing a gameAll this is due to the fact that the game was designed for you to choose which of the four areas you wanted to explore first; and this is where the game gets hindered. Because the developers chose to provide a sense of open exploration, and make the world "open" they didn't change enemy types, difficulty or change much of anything in all 4 major areas. this failure to either not decide how to unfold the story or make a simplistic game was what lead to further downfalls. By the second area you are basically just rinse and repeating most if not all your actions. Again because the world was made "open for players to choose their own path" some dialogue between the two main characters feels out of place, with dialogue that should happen later in the game happening early in; and dialogue later in the game sounding like they just met.The ending is the straw that breaks the back of this camel, when you are forced to undo everything you had worked to accomplish during the game because the writers believed that at this point you felt invested/cared for the female character. 												Prince of Persia (2008) was a reboot of the Prince of Persia franchise with a new protagonist as the hero. It was meant to lead into a series of games, but due to poor fan and reviewer rerception this didn't happen. I initially brought the game with some trepidation, but find the game an atmospheric, mesmerising experience. However there are flaws in the game.In reviewing this I will try to avoid spoilers, as I want people to enjoy the story for what it is.The game title is a bit of a fallacy, as the hero is a bit of a rogue in the story and does not seem to have any of the royal background of the Prince from the Sands trilogy. However while initially disliking the guy, as I played through the story he grew on me.The background essentially is that during the opening "tutorial section" of the game an Evil god, Ahriman is "freed" from captivity and spreads corruption throughout the land. It then becomes your job to "aid" the Princess Elika in cleansing the land of corruption prevent Ahriman regaining his full strength and escaping the temple where he has been imprisoned.Elika is a constant companion in the game. following you assisting in the fights and her magic powers are both a key to cleansing the "Fertile lands" of corruption and traversing each of the four main areas of the game. Each area is governed by one of four corrupted bosses. The Hunter, the Alchemist, The Concubine and the Gaurdian. Initially only four starting areas are available to you as Elika no access to the magic to access the fertile lands anywhere else. In each of the four areas, you are introduced the the Aforementioned bosses. After traversing the areas obstacles and jumps, and defeating the corrupted, Elika is able to cleanse the area which transforms the land from desolate wasteland to vibrant lush greenery, and activates "light seeds" throughout the specific area to collect. Collect enough lightseeds and you can return to the temple courtyard to activate one of four powers. This then enables to traverse deeper into the land to further cleanse it, and therefore reteive new seeds to unlock further powers.You are not restricted in the order in which you unlock the powers, so essentially each playthrough can be a slightly different experience. This is due to the fact that as you progress against the four corrupted leaders, they gradually unleash other obstacles to overcome throughout the further levels. Once you have cleared all four sections of a bosses area. You are able to access a final fight with the specific boss. Defat all four and you return to the temple to finally defeat Ahriman.It should be noted that although you need the four powers to access the fertile grounds, that you are able to traverse the outskirts of every area at the start of the game. This is required as the powers only access limited areas. Elika will tell you which areas as you ponder the power to use. As you clease the Fertile Lands, you eventually are able to teleport between cleansed areas to reduce travel using the map screen. The map screen will also allow you to set a waypoint so that Elika can use her magic to guide you should you become lost.The "Prince" is an agile fellow, with a gauntlet to help him climb and slide down walls and traverse ceilings, and wall running abilities and jumping to boot. Couple that with Elika being able to assist him by boosting some jumps with her magic and saving you should you fall, or fail in battle. And he needs it to as the lands require all of his acrobatic skills to traverse the fantastical obstacles. This however brings to light the difference between Sands of Time and this game. In The Sands of Time you were traversing a Palace corrupted through the Sands of Time being unleashed. Each are felt "real" and that it could exist in a fantastical sense. The World of this Prince of Persia although well constructed is filled with floating islands and walls. A lot of the jumps require timed button presses to continue traversing the area. Fail and Elika will save you and return you to the first bit of flat land and the start of the sequence you failed.The final bugbear is in some of the fighting. Generally your combos are ties to Sword, Gauntlet, and Elika's Magic. Dodge with the jump button is occasionally required, but can be hard to pull off. In general you block as necessary with a timed block allowing you time to counterattack. As the game progresses, the corrupted introduce powers that require you to learn and counter with the correct move. Failing to use the move will mean that you will be unable to damage the corrupted and Elika can even be taken out of the fight requiring you to manuever to help her recover. Some enemy attacks can only be countered via quicktime button events, including manic button mashing (specifically needed for one particular boss every time you fight him, but occasionally used elsewhere).However you are aside from the four bosses you are limited to essentially only one other main enemy combatant throughout the game, albeit combat in general is used sparingly. The rest of the additions throughout the game are new obstacles to dodge in the corrupted lands. Once cleansed the focus is re-traversing the areas to figure out how to get every light seed within the game. No new obstacles are introduced into the cleansed areas. Although it can be fun to get the lightseeds it can also feel boring as there is no further combat in the cleansed areas.So why do I recommend it. Story and Visuals and Sound.The story (penned by Rhianna Pratchett) is charming and compelling and a the relationship that develops between the Prince and Elika is a joy to behold. This is further enhanced by the visuals which use a cel shading technique throughour the game. The visuals are clear and detailed with a lot of effort put in. As you cleanse each area the corruption is replaced with bright colours, blades of grass evident with a multitude of flowers and butterflies. The interaction between the Prince and Elika is further cemented by little things such as the way they change places on a thin ledge, how he will help her up in certain circumstances.Elika is not just eye candy however. she is truly an equal partner to the Prince. At no point is she relegated to escort duty, she never gets in the way and is crucial in the fights and puzzles as the game progresses. Sound through the game is beautiful. My last playthrough was on Windows 10 with a Creative Soundblaster Z and a Logitech 5.1 Surround Speaker set. I was suprised to find the eax dll within the game files. (The game only supports Windows Vista or later). Previously I had played on an Asus Xonar DX on the same speakers. With my current setup, positional sound was very clear, the music which Arabian themed is mesmerising ramping up and settling down as the situation demanded. Some people clain to have issue with sound using Realtek onboard sound cards, but as I have always played the game using discrete soundcards.The story, graphics and sound all combine to produce an incredible atmosphere in the game which compells me on. I am on my third playthrough still enjoying the atmosphere immensely.That said, due to the mechanics the game does lack challenge. (I miss the days when you were actually required to stay alive to complete the game). You will fall, but Elika will always save you. This can make it frustrating in one of the last levels as you are in is constantly retried again and again. The resolution is limited to 1920x41080 maximum and graphic options are accessed through the game launcher. (There is a way to edit the Windows registry to enable you to play at 4k resolutions. and my last playthrough has been entirely at a 4k Resolution). Keyboard and Mouse or Xbox 360/ONE controller can be used to play the game and the keys are rebindable. (I recommend playing with a controller as this is my preferred method for this style of game).

												Despite the fact I had tons of fun playing this game, it will be the only Prince of Persia I don't recommend, and I don't recommend it for two reasons:First off, it's not a Prince of Persia game. I get that they were trying to go new character, new kind of story, but really for all the differences between it and the feel of the games in the Sands of Time series, (which this is supposed to resemble), it really just has success by loose association. The platforming looks similar, but feels completely different. Plus, there is absolutely NO way to die. You have a partner with magic powers who will use them to catch you if you fall, push enemies off you before they can deliver deathblows, and pull you out of slime. This turns mistakes into minor inconveniences, instead of a need to restart. In the Sands of Time series, you could stop yourself from dying, but every time you use the Sands means that there's one less mistake you can make somewhere else. In this, Elika has seemingly unlimited power. This means you get unlimited restarts. You go back to the last place with solid ground. The enemy gets back the last round of damage you dealt to it. I think every element of this game is great and that they were all mixed together well. However, at the same time, it didn't feel like a challenge in the slightest. Even the Warrior, who you had to button mash to defeat and if you didn't send him over the edge he'd send you through the floor, never once stood a chance because you could survive ANYTHING thanks to Elika. On the topic of the Warrior, let's talk about the battle system. You had five main enemies to face, and some smaller soldiers along the way. The battle system was rebuilt around the fact you couldn't die. It was a fun battle system, but again it wasn't the free-form battle system I had come to expect from Prince of Persia. Yes, there were combos, but you really couldn't choose your own battle style. There were only two combos that did large amounts of damage: 4 sword strikes, or elika, elika, grapple, jump, elika, sword. Everything else was either there to push enemies into things, or the combos were just too short for damage to add up. Ubisoft could make a killing on a game based around this concept, but I wouldn't call it a Prince of Persia game and the system needs major refinement. Now, for the second thing I didn't like about the game: Story. Until the final sequence at the Temple, I thought it was fine. The intro was a bit weak, but hey, not every game deserves a cinematic. However, this is Prince of Persia. Ubisoft has made the whole series around a theatrical experience, and then they suddenly killed it in this one. Again, I get they were trying to go new hero, new kind of experience, but, as much as I like to bash Call of Duty for not innovating, They at least know that people like to play games with the same title for the same sort of experience. They changed this one a bit too much from the Sands of Time formula. Anyway, back to my problems with the plot. Other than the intro and the ending, it was actually fine. You had four different areas to explore and you could do them in whatever order you wanted. The plotline was built in such a way that it didn't matter which one you went to first. That was nice. However, I had to restart the game at one point because of a thoughtless error on Ubisoft's part. It didn't matter which power you unlocked first. However, the one that you choose second pretty much has to be the one that lets you progress further into the same area you were just in. Which means that you have to face down one boss at a time, four, maybe five times in a row. They make him "harder" every time, but it doesn't make a difference because you can't die. I had to restart the game because I chose the wrong second power. The Hunter in my opinion was the easiest to defeat, so I wanted to save him for last. However, becaue I chose to fight him after gaining my first power, it meant I couldn't possibly get enough pickups from the areas I had access to to unlock the third power. This forced me to COMPLETELY RESTART THE GAME!!! Now, I'm gonna try and talk about the ending without any spoilers. The whole game (when I played through the way Ubisoft wanted me to) had a pretty nice flow. You couldn't really get lost unless you found a way to skip cutscenes. So here's pretty much how it goes: weak beginning, good flow, good flow, good flow, good flow, mostly stable climax, panicked platforming sequence, then WTF? As far as I can tell I didn't accidentally choose an alternate ending. Your unnamed character undoes everything you worked so hard for the whole game, and it's not even like one of those "rewind" endings. If it was, I might not be so upset. This was an ending where he saves the world, changes his mind, and then ends it. Thanks a lot, Ubisoft! I thought this was supposed to be a reboot. How are you supposed to return to a world that NO LONGER EXISTS????I had fun. I'd probably play again. I just couldn't justify this to someone unless they enjoyed this kind of plot.
